elements.content: Two novel microporous metal−organic frameworks, {[Pr3(ATPT)2(HATPT)4]·(NO3)·8H2O} n (1) and {[Nd3(ATPT)3(HATPT)3]·9H2O} n (2) (H2ATPT = 2-aminoterephthalic acid), were synthesized by slow diffusion of aqueous solution of H2ATPT and Pr(NO3)3·6H2O or Nd(NO3)3·6H2O in 2-propanol. X-ray diffraction analyses reveal that their three-dimensional structures are composed of ATPT spacers and trinulcear lanthanide nodes, in which there are two crystallographically independent lanthanide atoms, nine- and twelve-coordinated. Twelve ATPT anions, adopting an unprecedented pentadentate η1:η1:η1:η2 bridging coordination mode, ligate the trinuclear node. Each pair of ATPT anions acts as a double bridge and is considered as one connection. Thus each trinuclear core is connected to the six nearest Ln3 neighbors forming a NaCl-type crystal lattice with a three-dimensional intersecting channel system of ca. 1.3-nm spacing between the centers of the adjacent clusters. The guest water molecules located in the large cavities can be removed without ruining the microporous framework. Thermal gravimetric and powder X-ray diffraction analyses confirm that small molecules, four methanol molecules per Pr3 unit and six methanol molecules per Nd3 unit, respectively, can be absorbed into the dehydrated microporous frameworks.

elements.content: The syntheses, crystal structures, and desorption/adsorption properties of two novel microporous metal−organic frameworks assembled by the secondary building units of linear trinuclear lanthanide clusters and organic spacers of 2-aminoterephthalic acid were reported.

elements.content: A number of coordination polymers have been synthesized over the past decade, providing a variety of infinite frameworks containing single and/or polynuclear metal ion cores and linkages. In particular, open metal−organic frameworks are of current interest as a new class of porous materials because these materials have shown new porous functions, for example, heterogeneous catalysis, anion exchange, and molecular adsorption and storage. These characteristic features are based on these materials' robust open framework, which leads to a permanent porosity in the crystal structure that can accommodate various guest molecules. Compared with conventionally used microporous inorganic materials such as zeolite, these organic structures have the potential for more flexible rational design, through control of the architecture and functionalization of the pores. The wide variety of possible organic linkers and the multiple physical properties of inorganic metal ions makes it feasible to modulate both the dimensions of the pores and the properties of the final porous frameworks. In such structures, organic species act as either pillars or linkers to arrange inorganic layers, chains, or clusters of transition or lanthanide ions. Although the flexibility of the coordination sphere of lanthanide ions makes design difficult, this pliability or coordinative ambivalence, coupled with the tendency of lanthanides to adopt high coordination numbers, makes the f-block metal ions attractive for the discovery of new and unusual networks. As some early work in this area, the first assembly of discrete cubane-like [Ln4(μ3-OH)4]8+ clusters into a three-dimensional microporous network via conventional solution reaction was described by selecting α-amino acids with dicarboxylic groups (l-aspartic and l-glutamic acid) as supporting ligands. Recently, a hydroxo-bridged heptanuclear lanthanide cluster [Ln7(μ3-OH)8]13+ as a building block to form a three-dimensional framework through the linkage of a linear 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylate has also been reported. However, in contrast to the well-established cluster chemistry of transition metals, the analogous chemistry of lanthanides, especially the assembly of discrete lanthanide clusters into three-dimensional microporous frameworks, is still less developed.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

A number of coordination polymers have been synthesized over the past decade, providing a variety of infinite frameworks containing single and/or polynuclear metal ion cores and linkages. In particular, open metal-organic frameworks are of current interest as a new class of porous materials because these materials have shown new porous functions, for example, heterogeneous catalysis, anion exchange, and molecular adsorption and storage. These characteristic features are based on these materials' robust open framework, which leads to a permanent porosity in the crystal structure that can accommodate various guest molecules. Compared with conventionally used microporous inorganic materials such as zeolite, these organic structures have the potential for more flexible rational design, through control of the architecture and functionalization of the pores. The wide variety of possible organic linkers and the multiple physical properties of inorganic metal ions makes it feasible to modulate both the dimensions of the pores and the properties of the final porous frameworks. In such structures, organic species act as either pillars or linkers to arrange inorganic layers, chains, or clusters of transition or lanthanide ions. Although the flexibility of the coordination sphere of lanthanide ions makes design difficult, this pliability or coordinative ambivalence, coupled with the tendency of lanthanides to adopt high coordination numbers, makes the f-block metal ions attractive for the discovery of new and unusual networks. As some early work in this area, the first assembly of discrete cubane-like [Ln4(μ3-OH)4]8+ clusters into a three-dimensional microporous network via  conventional solution reaction was described by selecting α-amino acids with dicarboxylic groups (l-aspartic and l-glutamic acid) as supporting ligands. Recently, a hydroxo-bridged heptanuclear lanthanide cluster [Ln7(μ3-OH)8]13+ as a building block to form a three-dimensional framework through the linkage of a linear 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylate has also been reported. However, in contrast to the well-established cluster chemistry of transition metals, the analogous chemistry of lanthanides, especially the assembly of discrete lanthanide clusters into three-dimensional microporous frameworks, is still less developed.

elements.content: On the other hand, in the study of metal−organic frameworks, rigid polycarboxylic acids, especially dicarboxylic acids, are frequently used to link metal ions or clusters. For example, the rodlike ligand terephthalic acid (tp) is a good spacer and has been widely used to fabricate large, tightly bound metal cluster aggregates. The earlier work involving the copolymerization of tp with metal ions pointed out that its rigid, planar, and divergent attributes would be ideally suited in forming the target-extended microporous frameworks. However, much less work has been carried out to investigate metal−organic frameworks of tp derivatives, for example, 2-aminoterephthalic acid (H2ATPT). The modification of tp is valuable for preparing more metal−organic zeolite analogues. For ATPT, the substituted amino group may affect the coordination mode of the carboxylic group or be coordinated by metal ions while the complexes are assembling.

The earlier work involving the copolymerization of tp with metal ions pointed out that its rigid, planar, and divergent attributes would be ideally suited in forming the target-extended microporous frameworks. However, much less work has been carried out to investigate metal-organic frameworks of tp derivatives, for example, 2-aminoterephthalic acid (H2ATPT). The modification of tp is valuable for preparing more metal-organic zeolite analogues. For ATPT, the substituted amino group may affect the coordination mode of the carboxylic group or be coordinated by metal ions while the complexes are assembling.

elements.content: Here, we report two intriguing microporous frameworks, {[Pr3(ATPT)2(HATPT)4]·(NO3)·8H2O} n (1) and {[Nd3(ATPT)3(HATPT)3]·9H2O} n (2), which crystallize in the high symmetry of cubic crystal system, space group Ia-3, and consist of trinuclear lanthanide clusters constituting so-called secondary building units (SBUs). Each Ln3 cluster is connected to another Ln3 cluster via two ATPT anions as a double bridge and surrounded by six Ln3 clusters through twelve ATPT anions as the nearest neighbors. Notably, the ATPT anion adopts an unusual pentadentate η1:η1:η1:η2 coordination mode, which is observed for the first time. The ATPT anions link the Ln3 nodes into an extended network possessing a three-dimensional intersecting channel system of ca. 1.3-nm spacing between the centers of the adjacent clusters. To the best of our knowledge, it is the first report of the assembly of linear trinuclear lanthanide clusters into a microporous framework. Remarkably, the 3D framework remains intact after removal of guest water molecules trapped in the cavity and after methanol replacing the guest water molecules.

Notably, the ATPT anion adopts an unusual pentadentate η1:η1:η1:η2 coordination mode, which is observed for the first time. The ATPT anions link the Ln3 nodes into an extended network possessing a three-dimensional intersecting channel system of ca. 1.3-nm spacing between the centers of the adjacent clusters. To the best of our knowledge, it is the first report of the assembly of linear trinuclear lanthanide clusters into a microporous framework. Remarkably, the 3D framework remains intact after removal of guest water molecules trapped in the cavity and after methanol replacing the guest water molecules.

elements.content: Materials and Physical Techniques. Methanol was treated with a molecular sieve. Other reagents and solvents were commercially available and used as received without further purification. Analyses for C, H, and N were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer analyzer at the Institute of Elemento-Organic Chemistry, Nankai University. IR spectrum was recorded in a KBr disk on a Bruker Tensor 27 IR spectrophotometer in the 4000−600-cm-1 region. Powder X-ray diffraction measurements were recorded on a D/Max-2500 X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation. Thermal analyses (under oxygenated atmosphere, heating rate of 5 °C/min) were carried out in a Labsys NETZSCH TG 209 Setaram apparatus.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 Materials and Physical Techniques. Methanol was treated with a molecular sieve. Other reagents and solvents were commercially available and used as received without further purification. Analyses for C, H, and N were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer analyzer at the Institute of Elemento-Organic Chemistry, Nankai University. IR spectrum was recorded in a KBr disk on a Bruker Tensor 27 IR spectrophotometer in the 4000-600-cm-1 region. Powder X-ray diffraction measurements were recorded on a D/Max-2500 X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation. Thermal analyses (under oxygenated atmosphere, heating rate of 5 °C/min) were carried out in a Labsys NETZSCH TG 209 Setaram apparatus.

elements.content: Preparation of {[Pr3(ATPT)2(HATPT)4]·(NO3)·8H2O} n (1):  NaOH (0.1 M) was added dropwise to 10 mL water solution of H2ATPT (0.018 g, 0.10 mmol) adjusting the pH value to ca. ∼5−6. A solution of Pr(NO3)3·6H2O (0.044 g, 0.10 mmol) in 2-propanol (8 mL) was allowed to slowly diffuse into the above solution of H2ATPT through a buffering layer of 2-propanol and water (1:1). Crystals suitable for X-ray crystal analyses were obtained after several days, which are stable in air and insoluble in water and common organic solvents. Yield:  35%. IR data (KBr pellet, υ/cm-1):  3450 s, 3370 m, 1620 s, 1540 m, 1490 m, 1420 vs, 1360 s. Elemental analysis (%) calcd for 1·7H2O:  C, 31.44; H, 3.51; N, 5.34. Found:  C, 31.36; H, 3.94; N, 5.11. The crystals for elemental analysis adsorb additional water molecules due to the large porosity. That the crystals used for crystal structure determination do not possess so many lattice water molecules may be due to the presence of the organic solvent in the crystal growth of 1.

elements.content: Preparation of {[Nd3(ATPT)3(HATPT)3]·9H2O} n (2):  The synthetic procedure was similar to that of 1 except that Pr(NO3)3·6H2O was replaced by Nd(NO3)3·6H2O (0.044 g, 0.10 mmol). Suitable crystals, stable in air and insoluble in water and common organic solvents, were obtained after a week. Yield:  30%. IR data (KBr pellet, υ/cm-1):  3400 s, 3350 m, 1630 s, 1540 m, 1450 m, 1415 vs, 1315 m. Elemental analysis (%) calcd for 2·9H2O:  C, 31.47; H, 3.63; N, 4.59. Found:  C, 31.03; H, 3.37; N, 5.05. The additional water molecules are owed to the same reason as that of 1.

elements.content: Crystal Structure Determination. Diffraction intensities for complexes 1 and 2 were collected on a computer-controlled Bruker SMART 1000 CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation with radiation wavelength 0.71073 Å by using the ω-scan technique. Lorentz polarization and absorption corrections were applied. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 programs. Anisotropic thermal parameters were assigned to all non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms were set in calculated positions and refined as riding atoms with a common fixed isotropic thermal parameter. Analytical expressions of neutral-atom scattering factors were employed, and anomalous dispersion corrections were incorporated. The crystallographic data, selected bond lengths, and angles for 1 and 2 are listed in Table and Table , respectively. CCDC258593 (1) and 258594 (2) contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.can.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html.

Crystal Structures of 1 and 2. The X-ray structure analyses reveal that 1 and 2 are isostructural, crystallizing in the high symmetry of cubic crystal system, space group Ia-3. The molecular motifs of the two complexes display extreme similarity with slight differences in the number of anions and lattice water molecules. Both 1 and 2 possess NaCl-type three-dimensional networks composed of ATPT spacers and trinuclear lanthanide nodes, in which two crystallographically independent Ln atoms (Pr (1) and Nd (2)) are observed. The structure may be derived from a simple cubic six-connected NaCl-type lattice in two stages:  first, the nodes (vertexes) of the net are replaced by clusters of secondary building units; second, the links (edges) of the net are replaced by finite rods of ATPT molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 Crystal Structures of 1 and 2. The X-ray structure analyses reveal that 1 and 2 are isostructural, crystallizing in the high symmetry of cubic crystal system, space group Ia-3. The molecular motifs of the two complexes display extreme similarity with slight differences in the number of anions and lattice water molecules. Both 1 and 2 possess NaCl-type three-dimensional networks composed of ATPT spacers and trinuclear lanthanide nodes, in which two crystallographically independent Ln atoms (Pr (1) and Nd (2)) are observed. The structure may be derived from a simple cubic six-connected NaCl-type lattice in two stages: first, the nodes (vertexes) of the net are replaced by clusters of secondary building units; second, the links (edges) of the net are replaced by finite rods of ATPT molecules.

elements.content: Here complex 1 is taken as an example to depict the three-dimensional structure in detail. Two crystallographically different lanthanide atoms (Pr1 and Pr2) in 1 are shown in Figure . Pr1 atom lies in the coordination geometry of a distorted tricapped trigonal prism with six oxygen atoms from three ATPT anions (Pr1−O1 (O1A or O1B), 2.536(6) Å; Pr1−O2 (O2A or O2B), 2.527(7) Å) and three oxygen atoms from another three ATPT anions (Pr1−O4A (O4B or O4C), 2.469(6) Å). The metal−oxygen bond lengths are within the range of those usually encountered for 9-fold lanthanide-oxygen coordination. The dihedral angle between O1A−Pr1−O2A and O1B−Pr1−O2B is 94.2(3)°. The Pr2 atom is twelve-coordinated by six chelating carboxylic groups from six ATPT anions forming an icosahedron:  Pr2−O3A, 2.633(7) Å; Pr2−O4A, 2.672(6) Å with the O3A−Pr2−O4A angle of 48.9(2)°. The dihedral angle between O3A−Pr2−O4A and O3B−Pr2−O4B is 100.3(4)°. The ATPT anions connect such two different coordinated Pr atoms composing a trinuclear cluster (Figure , the coordination environment of Pr1A is the same as that of Pr1):  two oxygen atoms of one carboxylic group (O3A and O4A, for instance) chelate to Pr2, and at the same time one of the two oxygen atoms (O4A) bridges Pr1 and Pr2 centers (Pr1−O4A−Pr2, 101.0(2)°). There are three oxygen bridges between the Pr1(Pr1A) and Pr2 atoms with the Pr1(Pr1A)···Pr2 distance of 3.970(4) Å. The dihedral angles between planes consisted of bridged oxygen atom, Pr1 and Pr2 are all 120.0(2)°. The Pr1, Pr2, and Pr1A atoms are strictly in a line with the Pr1···Pr1A distance of 7.939(5) Å, and Pr2 atom locates on the symmetric center of the trinuclear unit. Compared with the reported trinuclear lanthanide clusters, most of which possess a V-shaped geometry, such a strictly linear arrangement with so high symmetry is rather rare.

elements.content: For charge neutralization, it is suggested that some of the ligands are not deprotonated completely but exist as HATPT. Thus there are two types of ligands presented in the formulas of compounds 1 and 2. Since all of the carboxylic oxygen atoms are involved in the coordination to metal ions and the C−O and M−O bond lengths vary slightly, it is more proper that the nonprotonated hydrogen atom is attached to the nitrogen atom of the amino group. However, the amino group itself in the organic ligand is disordered and this hydrogen atom cannot be detected in the difference map. The ATPT molecules have the same pentadentate η1:η1:η1:η2 coordination mode (Chart a). Such an unprecedented coordination mode plays an important role in the formation of the trinuclear cluster. The amino group in H2ATPT is disordered and serves merely as a “spectator” fragment, which affects the structure of the complex only by imposing electrostatic and/or steric effect.

elements.content: The trinuclear cluster is further connected to each other via the ATPT bridges. Although twelve bridging ligands ligate each trinuclear core, each trinuclear cluster is bridged to the six nearest neighbors because a pair of ATPT ligands forms a “double bridge” and is considered as one connection (Figure a). Similar double bridges have been observed in some high connected lanthanide coordination networks, [La(L4)]·(BPh4)·(ClO4)2·2.75CH3OH and [La(L4)]·([Co(C2H11B9)2])3·0.5CH3OH (L = 4,4‘-bipyridine-N,N‘-dioxide), in which the existence of one and two double bridges reduces them to be seven- and six-connected networks, respectively. In our title complex, the coexistence of six double bridges is rather rare.

elements.content: Along each direction, the double ATPT bridges link the trinuclear lanthanide cores into a steplike one-dimensional chain (Figure b):  four Pr atoms comprise a highly distorted grid with dimensions of 3.970 × 11.681 Å; the two sides composed of Pr atoms are actually perpendicular, and the benzene rings of ATPT anions constituting the other two sides are almost parallel with the dihedral angle of 4.2(3)°. In such arrangements, two benzene rings of ATPT overlap, in which the distances between the atoms in one benzene ring and the other benzene ring are in the range of 3.352(3)−3.597(3) Å, indicating the π···π interactions between two benzene rings. Every trinuclear core is involved in three infinite steplike chains, which form a NaCl-type crystal lattice with the trinuclear core as a 6-fold connectivity. As shown in Figure , the one-dimensional steplike chain (viewed down the a axis) is further connected by ATPT bridges in the b and c directions, which creates a highly ordered three-dimensional intersecting channel system with 13.514-Å spacing between the centers of the adjacent clusters.

elements.content: The NaCl-type crystal lattice unit is formed by eight trinuclear cores as vertexes and ATPT bridges as the sides of the cube, which contains water molecules and nitric anions (Figure ). Calculations from the X-ray structure parameters show that the solvent accessible void space in the cube is approximately 23.3%. When the lattice water molecules are removed, the volume increases up to 47.9%, close to that observed in [Zn4O(bdc)3(DMF)8(C6H5Cl)] (bdc = bezenedicarboxylate), which is regarded as the prototype for a third generation of open frameworks. In [Zn4O(bdc)3(DMF)8(C6H5Cl)], a regular Zn4O tetrahedron is linked by O2−C−C6H4−C−O2 struts to give an extended network containing a three-dimensional intersecting channel with a spacing between the centers of the adjacent clusters of 12.94 Å.

elements.content: The coordination environment of the trinuclear cluster of 2 is in the Supporting Information. It is noticeable that, for 2, the dimension of the cuboidal box, which can accommodate lattice water molecules, is about 13.433 Å (defined by two central Nd atoms in the trinuclear cores, respectively). A PLATON program analysis suggests that there is approximately 38.7% of the crystal volume accessible to the solvents. This value is large among the known microporous networks. The remarkably large solvent-accessible void space in complex 2 can be explained by the absence of the nitric anions. When the lattice water molecules are removed, the volume increases up to 51.0%.

elements.content: Synthesis. The most favorably used synthetic methods for lanthanide and organic acids are hydrothermal or solvothermal syntheses. The published systems of H2ATPT and lanthanides are all carried out under the temperature scope of 140−160 °C in a Teflon-lined stainless autoclave. Zheng et al. once reported a series of [Ln(ATPT)1.5(H2O)2]·2H2O (Ln = La, Nd, Dy, Eu, Tb), [Pr2(ATPT)3(H2O)5]·2H2O, and [Er2(ATPT)3(H2O)4]·1.5H2O polymers, which all crystallize in a triclinic crystal system, space group P-1. The lanthanide atoms are all eight-coordinated with carboxylic oxygen atoms and two or three coordinated water molecules. In these complexes, the ATPT anions adopt three kinds of coordination modes, c, d, and h in Chart , and the Ln/ATPT ratio is 2/3. While in complexes 1 and 2, two geometrically different lanthanide centers coexist in one complex with higher coordination numbers, nine and twelve. Noticeably, there are no coordinated water molecules and the lanthanide atoms are all furnished with carboxylic oxygen atoms. The ATPT anion employs a previously unknown coordination mode, a, in Chart , and the Ln/ATPT ratio is 1/2. The above obvious differences lead to the formation of the microporous framework with high symmetrical cubic system of space group Ia-3, which is rather rare for lanthanide−carboxylate systems. The ultimate reason may arise from the synthetic procedure:  (i) The present experiment was carried out under the mild condition via slow diffusion of water/2-propanol solution containing reactants. Immediate suspension was observed when lanthanide salt was added to ATPT solution directly. The slow-diffusion method has been proved to be effective for cyanide-bridged systems to obtain crystals suitable for X-ray analysis, which permits the formation of dynamically stable structures. Whereas the hydrothermal synthesis, commonly used for lanthanide−carboxylate system, is in favor of thermodynamically stable complexes. Here the attempt of employing the slow-diffusion method in the lanthanide−ATPT system gives birth to two high symmetrical cubic crystal structures with trinuclear clusters as six-connecting nodes and ATPT anions as spacers. (ii) The pH value of the reacting system may have subtle influence on the structural formation. Structures controlled by pH values have been reported. We just adjusted the pH value of ATPT solution to ca. ∼5−6, while in Zheng's paper, equal molar concentrations of ATPT and NaOH were introduced which made the ultimate resultant pH value even lower. The different acidity may have some delicate contributions to the structure formation.

elements.content: Thermal Stability and Adsorption Property of 1. The existence of guest molecules in the microporous frameworks inspired us to investigate the thermal stability of the frameworks. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) for crystal sample 1 was performed from 25 to 600 °C (Figure a). The weight loss of 15.16% in the range 25−120 °C corresponds to the loss of all uncoordinated water molecules plus adsorbed water molecules (calculated 14.72% for 1·7H2O), which indicates the adsorption of seven water molecules per Pr3 unit of 1, and is consistent with elemental analysis (EA) of 1·7H2O. A similar case has been observed previously. The further weight decrease of 4.04% from 180 to 270 °C suggests the loss of nitric anions (calculated 3.38%). The weight loss above 270 °C may be due to the release of amino groups in the ligands and stepwise decomposation of the complex. To further test whether the framework would break down on removal of the guest water molecules, we examined the powder samples by X-ray diffraction analysis. Guest water molecules were removed by heating 1 at 120 °C for 10 h. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns of 1 and dehydrated samples of 1 are nearly identical. The positions of the major peaks undergo no significant changes and only the intensity of some peaks varies, which support the notion that the crystal lattice remains intact after the lattice water molecules have been removed (Figure ). The above results stimulated us to further investigate whether 1 would adsorb other small molecules such as methanol due to the giant pores. {[Pr3 (ATPT)2(HATPT)4]·(NO3)·4CH3OH} n (1a) was obtained as follows:  first, 1 was heated for 10 h at 120 °C, then it was immersed in methanol for 12 h. To decrease the account of trace water, the methanol has been treated with a molecular sieve beforehand. The results of TGA and EA reveal that the complex adsorbs four methanol molecules after the loss of all uncoordinated water molecules per Pr3 unit. The weight loss of 7.65% in 1a from 20 to 150 °C means the removal of adsorbed methanol molecules (calculated 7.58%), and with further increase in temperature to 220 °C, the weight loss of 3.51% indicates the loss of the nitric anions (calculated 3.66% for 1a). Powder X-ray diffraction of 1a supports the nature that the crystal lattice retains its integrity even after methanol replaces guest water molecules. The simulated patterns calculated from the single-crystal structure of 1 is in good agreement with the observed ones (Figure a), which confirms the same crystal lattice of the crystal from which the crystal structure was obtained and the remaining sample which was used for elemental analyses.

elements.content: Thermal Stability and Adsorption Property of 2. Because of the structural similarities of 1 and 2, we deduced that complex 2 could have similar thermal stability and adsorption property to that of complex 1. TGA reveals that complex 2 can also adsorb water molecules as a consequence of the large pores. TGA was performed on the crystalline sample of 2 in the range of 25−600 °C, as shown in Figure . The weight loss of 17.83% for 2 between 25 and 120 °C corresponds to the loss of all uncoordinated and adsorbed water molecules (calcd 17.70% for 2·9H2O). This is indicative of the adsorption of nine water molecules per Nd3 unit of 2, which is consistent with the EA of 2·9H2O. Water molecules were removed by heating 2 at 120 °C for 10 h. {[Nd3(ATPT)3(HATPT)3]·6CH3OH} n (2a) was obtained by the same procedure as that of 1a. The results of TGA and EA reveal that the complex adsorbs six methanol molecules after the loss of all uncoordinated water molecules per Nd3 unit. The weight loss of 12.06% of 2a from 20 to 150 °C means the removal of adsorbed methanol molecules (calculated 11.31%). Powder X-ray diffraction patterns of 2 and dehydrated samples of 2 and 2a are nearly identical, which support the notion that the crystal lattice remains intact after the guest water molecules have been removed and even when methanol replaced guest water molecules (Figure ).

elements.content: In summary, we have synthesized two microporous metal−organic frameworks, {[Pr3(ATPT)2(HATPT)4]·(NO3)·8H2O} n (1) and {[Nd3(ATPT)3(HATPT)3]·9H2O} n (2). They all crystallize in the high geometry cubic of space group Ia-3, composed of the secondary building blocks of trinuclear lanthanide cores as six-connecting nodes, which are enclosed by twelve ATPT bridges. Interestingly, a pair of ATPT anions acts as a double bridge, of which the pentadentate η1:η1:η1:η2 coordination mode is first observed. The bridging of the Ln3 SBUs forms a NaCl-type crystal lattice containing cavities occupied by guest molecules. To the best of our knowledge, it is the first observation of the assembly of the linear trinuclear lanthanide clusters into a microporous framework. Thermal gravimetric and powder X-ray diffraction analyses show that the large cavity can accommodate other small molecules such as methanol after removal of the guest water molecules. Most importantly, the host structure remains intact during the course. The ATPT ligand, as a good spacer, can be exploited to create novel lanthanide-containing materials providing microporous structures. The large size of the cavities offers appreciable potential for the guest molecule occupation and investigation in this direction is in progress.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we have synthesized two microporous metal-organic frameworks, {[Pr3(ATPT)2(HATPT)4]⋅(NO3)⋅8H2O} n  (1) and {[Nd3(ATPT)3(HATPT)3]⋅9H2O} n  (2). They all crystallize in the high geometry cubic of space group Ia-3, composed of the secondary building blocks of trinuclear lanthanide cores as six-connecting nodes, which are enclosed by twelve ATPT bridges. Interestingly, a pair of ATPT anions acts as a double bridge, of which the pentadentate η1:η1:η1:η2 coordination mode is first observed. The bridging of the Ln3 SBUs forms a NaCl-type crystal lattice containing cavities occupied by guest molecules. To the best of our knowledge, it is the first observation of the assembly of the linear trinuclear lanthanide clusters into a microporous framework. Thermal gravimetric and powder X-ray diffraction analyses show that the large cavity can accommodate other small molecules such as methanol after removal of the guest water molecules. Most importantly, the host structure remains intact during the course. The ATPT ligand, as a good spacer, can be exploited to create novel lanthanide-containing materials providing microporous structures. The large size of the cavities offers appreciable potential for the guest molecule occupation and investigation in this direction is in progress.

cln_elements.content:
Preparation of {[Pr3(ATPT)2(HATPT)4]·(NO3)·8H2O} n (1):  NaOH (0.1 M) was added dropwise to 10 mL water solution of H2ATPT (0.018 g, 0.10 mmol) adjusting the pH value to ca. ∼5−6. A solution of Pr(NO3)3·6H2O (0.044 g, 0.10 mmol) in 2-propanol (8 mL) was allowed to slowly diffuse into the above solution of H2ATPT through a buffering layer of 2-propanol and water (1:1). Crystals suitable for X-ray crystal analyses were obtained after several days, which are stable in air and insoluble in water and common organic solvents. Yield:  35%. IR data (KBr pellet, υ/cm-1):  3450 s, 3370 m, 1620 s, 1540 m, 1490 m, 1420 vs, 1360 s. Elemental analysis (%) calcd for 1·7H2O:  C, 31.44; H, 3.51; N, 5.34. Found:  C, 31.36; H, 3.94; N, 5.11. The crystals for elemental analysis adsorb additional water molecules due to the large porosity. That the crystals used for crystal structure determination do not possess so many lattice water molecules may be due to the presence of the organic solvent in the crystal growth of 1.

Preparation of {[Nd3(ATPT)3(HATPT)3]·9H2O} n (2):  The synthetic procedure was similar to that of 1 except that Pr(NO3)3·6H2O was replaced by Nd(NO3)3·6H2O (0.044 g, 0.10 mmol). Suitable crystals, stable in air and insoluble in water and common organic solvents, were obtained after a week. Yield:  30%. IR data (KBr pellet, υ/cm-1):  3400 s, 3350 m, 1630 s, 1540 m, 1450 m, 1415 vs, 1315 m. Elemental analysis (%) calcd for 2·9H2O:  C, 31.47; H, 3.63; N, 4.59. Found:  C, 31.03; H, 3.37; N, 5.05. The additional water molecules are owed to the same reason as that of 1.

Preparation of {[Nd3(ATPT)3(HATPT)3]⋅9H2O} n  (2): The synthetic procedure was similar to that of 1 except that Pr(NO3)3⋅6H2O was replaced by Nd(NO3)3⋅6H2O (0.044 g, 0.10 mmol). Suitable crystals, stable in air and insoluble in water and common organic solvents, were obtained after a week. Yield: 30%. IR data (KBr pellet, υ/cm-1): 3400 s, 3350 m, 1630 s, 1540 m, 1450 m, 1415 vs, 1315 m. Elemental analysis (%) calcd for 2⋅9H2O: C, 31.47; H, 3.63; N, 4.59. Found: C, 31.03; H, 3.37; N, 5.05. The additional water molecules are owed to the same reason as that of 1.

cln_elements.content:
The coordination environment of the trinuclear cluster of 2 is in the Supporting Information. It is noticeable that, for 2, the dimension of the cuboidal box, which can accommodate lattice water molecules, is about 13.433 Å (defined by two central Nd atoms in the trinuclear cores, respectively). A PLATON program analysis suggests that there is approximately 38.7% of the crystal volume accessible to the solvents. This value is large among the known microporous networks. The remarkably large solvent-accessible void space in complex 2 can be explained by the absence of the nitric anions. When the lattice water molecules are removed, the volume increases up to 51.0%.

Thermal Stability and Adsorption Property of 1. The existence of guest molecules in the microporous frameworks inspired us to investigate the thermal stability of the frameworks. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) for crystal sample 1 was performed from 25 to 600 °C (Figure a). The weight loss of 15.16% in the range 25−120 °C corresponds to the loss of all uncoordinated water molecules plus adsorbed water molecules (calculated 14.72% for 1·7H2O), which indicates the adsorption of seven water molecules per Pr3 unit of 1, and is consistent with elemental analysis (EA) of 1·7H2O. A similar case has been observed previously. The further weight decrease of 4.04% from 180 to 270 °C suggests the loss of nitric anions (calculated 3.38%). The weight loss above 270 °C may be due to the release of amino groups in the ligands and stepwise decomposation of the complex. To further test whether the framework would break down on removal of the guest water molecules, we examined the powder samples by X-ray diffraction analysis. Guest water molecules were removed by heating 1 at 120 °C for 10 h. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns of 1 and dehydrated samples of 1 are nearly identical. The positions of the major peaks undergo no significant changes and only the intensity of some peaks varies, which support the notion that the crystal lattice remains intact after the lattice water molecules have been removed (Figure ). The above results stimulated us to further investigate whether 1 would adsorb other small molecules such as methanol due to the giant pores. {[Pr3 (ATPT)2(HATPT)4]·(NO3)·4CH3OH} n (1a) was obtained as follows:  first, 1 was heated for 10 h at 120 °C, then it was immersed in methanol for 12 h. To decrease the account of trace water, the methanol has been treated with a molecular sieve beforehand. The results of TGA and EA reveal that the complex adsorbs four methanol molecules after the loss of all uncoordinated water molecules per Pr3 unit. The weight loss of 7.65% in 1a from 20 to 150 °C means the removal of adsorbed methanol molecules (calculated 7.58%), and with further increase in temperature to 220 °C, the weight loss of 3.51% indicates the loss of the nitric anions (calculated 3.66% for 1a). Powder X-ray diffraction of 1a supports the nature that the crystal lattice retains its integrity even after methanol replaces guest water molecules. The simulated patterns calculated from the single-crystal structure of 1 is in good agreement with the observed ones (Figure a), which confirms the same crystal lattice of the crystal from which the crystal structure was obtained and the remaining sample which was used for elemental analyses.

Thermal Stability and Adsorption Property of 2. Because of the structural similarities of 1 and 2, we deduced that complex 2 could have similar thermal stability and adsorption property to that of complex 1. TGA reveals that complex 2 can also adsorb water molecules as a consequence of the large pores. TGA was performed on the crystalline sample of 2 in the range of 25−600 °C, as shown in Figure . The weight loss of 17.83% for 2 between 25 and 120 °C corresponds to the loss of all uncoordinated and adsorbed water molecules (calcd 17.70% for 2·9H2O). This is indicative of the adsorption of nine water molecules per Nd3 unit of 2, which is consistent with the EA of 2·9H2O. Water molecules were removed by heating 2 at 120 °C for 10 h. {[Nd3(ATPT)3(HATPT)3]·6CH3OH} n (2a) was obtained by the same procedure as that of 1a. The results of TGA and EA reveal that the complex adsorbs six methanol molecules after the loss of all uncoordinated water molecules per Nd3 unit. The weight loss of 12.06% of 2a from 20 to 150 °C means the removal of adsorbed methanol molecules (calculated 11.31%). Powder X-ray diffraction patterns of 2 and dehydrated samples of 2 and 2a are nearly identical, which support the notion that the crystal lattice remains intact after the guest water molecules have been removed and even when methanol replaced guest water molecules (Figure ).
